WRITING.TEXT: I hope never to be in a yoga class practicing this pose.

At one point, the only thing that would calm my son was being in the bathroom, with the shower on (for white noise), strapped in a carrier, bouncing up and down, and singing to the melody of Edelweiss. My wife and I would have long conversations set to Edelweiss.
My point being: try everything in combination and eventually, eventually, you will hit on something.

WRITING.TEXT:
Upfront: I work for them. But the Boston Globe, in print and online, is pretty much the definitive source on city and state politics. Most of the content is now on the pay site, http://www.bostonglobe.com, but if you know how to Google, you can probably figure out how to read it for free (and links from Reddit or other social media will get you that article free). Kevin Cullen, Adrian Walker, and Yvonne Abraham are the go-to columnists, IMHO.
http://www.wbur.org is doing an increasingly good job of covering local politics.
Concrete doesn't burn, does it?
Also, the [archive of Globe coverage](http://boston.com/news/specials/whitey/) - see especially the old special reports in the lower-right column.

For downtown hotels without a discount, yes.
But you should be able to find reasonable rates outside of Downtown - check Brookline, for instance, for hotels that would be an MBTA ride away from the concert.
There's also a very nice, newly renovated [youth hostel](http://bostonhostel.org/)

If you think this has been downplayed by the media, perhaps you need to broaden your media diet.
It was the top story on Boston.com for a couple of days (http://www.pastpages.org/screenshot/837230/), as well as front-page news in the Globe and Herald. I know I heard it discussed on WBUR as well.

WRITING.TEXT: The Museum of Science offers Observatory Nights periodically - http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours. I'm sure the folks there could offer advice. As could the Amateur Telescope Makers of Boston - http://www.atmob.org/
The post is by the Executive Director of the Mass. ACLU. Although I grant you that she's a bit short on what concrete steps they're taking besides publicity.

I commute to Dorchester daily. Porter to JFK/UMass takes about 20 minutes - maybe 10 minutes more at rush hour when there's more waiting for the train ahead to clear a station. But it's a lot less stressful to sit in the train and chill than to sit in rush hour traffic on the Pike (and better for the environment, too).
The ACLU is on the case: http://boston.com/community/blogs/on_liberty/2013/05/targeting_teenage_rapper_smack.html
